utterances: He suggested this to Louis XIV as a way to raise money for the government to fight its wars, to pay for his mistresses, to finance deficits and so on and so forth.
...until you go into a concert hall and then you hear...
The U.S.
raid that killed Osama bin Laden also raised many questions about the nature of the U.S.-Pakistani relationship.
The U.S.
said it carried out the operation deep inside Pakistan without informing anyone in the Pakistan government or military.
And afterwards, Pakistan claimed it was completely unaware that bin Laden was living in a large Pakistani city.
Now, some American lawmakers are wondering whether U.S.
aid to Pakistan is really paying off.
NPR's Michele Kelemen reports.
Senator Carl Levin, a Michigan Democrat, says Pakistanis have some explaining to do.
The Pakistani army and intelligence have a lot of questions to answer, given the location, the length of time and the apparent fact that this facility was actually built for bin Laden.
Obama administration officials seem to be going out of their way, though, not to embarrass the Pakistani government in order to maintain whatever intelligence cooperation they still have.
Secretary of State Hillary Clinton stressed the positive when she spoke with reporters yesterday.
Our counterterrorism cooperation over a number of years now with Pakistan has contributed greatly to our efforts to dismantle al-Qaida.
And, in fact, cooperation with Pakistan helped lead us to bin Laden and the compound in which he was hiding.
But privately, U.S.
officials say they did not share intelligence with Pakistan before the raid that killed Osama bin Laden.
And it's not clear that Pakistanis even knew bin Laden was there, as White House counterterrorism advisor John Brennan points out.
They, at least in our discussions with them, seem as surprised as we were initially that bin Laden was holding out in that area.
That's not a very comforting thought for Richard Haass, president of the Council on Foreign Relations.
He was a top State Department official during the Bush administration and remembers having heart-to-heart talks with Pakistanis after 9/11.
I think in some ways you'll end up with another moment of truth with U.S.-Pakistani relations.
It'll be very hard to justify aid flows that are generous unless there is confidence that, again, Pakistan is a partner.
Haass told reporters in a conference call that the Pakistanis have a choice: either deal with the terrorist threat at home or accept the fact that the U.S.
will intervene.
He doesn't expect relations ever to get to the point where there is full confidence and trust.
It has been, is and will remain one of the most fraught, complicated and difficult relationships, literally, that exists in the world today.
Brennan, the White House advisor, says he and his colleagues are working through many of these issues with Pakistan now.
And he says Pakistanis understood why the U.S.
took action and appreciated the fact that the U.S.
kept casualties to a minimum.
We don't always agree on some of the things that we want to do, but through that continued dialogue and communication, I think we get where we need to be.

This is one more incident that we're going to have to deal with, and we look forward to continuing to work with our Pakistani colleagues, because they are as much, if not more, on the front lines of the battle against terrorism.
As Secretary of State Clinton tries to manage this complicated relationship, she's also trying to make a larger point to the Arab and Muslim world.

History will record that bin Laden's death came at a time of great movements toward freedom and democracy, at a time when the people across the Middle East and North Africa are rejecting the extremist narratives and charting a path of peaceful progress based on universal rights and aspirations.
There is no better rebuke to al-Qaida and its heinous ideology.
She's hoping now that Taliban fighters in Afghanistan will get that message, abandon al-Qaida and negotiate peace.
Michele Kelemen, NPR News, Washington.
On a Thursday morning it's MORNING EDITION from NPR News.
I'm Steve Inskeep.
You see the pictures in the society pages, photos of a socialite or business leader smiling at a charity gala.
These events generally raise money for worthy causes and most of the donors get a tax break for buying a ticket - a deduction for donating.
That's how much of philanthropic giving works in this country.
But one way President Obama hopes to reduce the budget deficit is by limiting those charitable deductions for people in the top income bracket.
Charities worry this will discourage people from giving.
Others are not so sure.
NPR's Elizabeth Blair has this report.
Americans are generous.
Over $300 billion in charitable contributions were made by corporations, individuals and foundations in 2009, according to Giving USA - the environment, education, healthcare, the arts.
The charitable sector is a very large sector.
Diana Aviv is head of Independent Sector, which lobbies on behalf of charities and non-profits.
We've got a million charities.
We've got 12 million full time employees.
Our collective budgets add up to about a trillion dollars.
And tax breaks make it cheaper for many people to give to these charities.
But making it cheaper comes at a cost.
Leonard Berman, a professor at Syracuse University, estimates the charitable deduction for 2011 will cost the federal government $49 billion.
It's not an insignificant amount of money.
Berman, a co-founder of the Tax Policy Center, says the charity deduction is like a lot of deductions: It provides the biggest breaks to the wealthiest donors.
And that's why President Obama is going after it.
His proposal would give them less of a tax break on their donations.
The logic behind it is basically this - you know, why should millionaires get a much bigger subsidy on their charitable contributions than people with modest incomes?
The charity deduction is a huge sacred cow.
To some it's a subsidy.
To others it's an incentive for people to give to non-profits that provide services government either can't or won't.
President Obama also tried, and failed, to reduce the value of charitable deductions about two years ago.
On average, 10 times faster - so downloading your movie 10 times faster or refreshing that webpage at those speed improvements - this is the difference between dial-up and broadband.
Meanwhile, the company isn't giving up on the franchise.
Munster says he expects Apple to release new phones this year with better screens and better cameras.
Laura Sydell, NPR News, San Francisco.
And now we turn to our roundtable, where we introduce you to E.R.
Shipp, professor of journalism at Hofstra University.
She's in our New York bureau.
George Curry, editor in chief of the National Newspaper Publishers Association News Service, joins us from Laurel, Maryland.
And Jeff Obafemi Carr, host of the radio show ""Freestyle,"" also joins us.
I should note that I'm here in Detroit today at WDET, and we thank them for housing us today, and we also want to welcome the listeners of WDET who have brought us on board recently.
Good to have a home here in my hometown.
All right, folks.
Professor E.R.
SHIPP (Hofstra University): Hello.
I don't even know where to start.
We've heard from the White House.
We've heard from pundit--conservative pundit Mychal Massie there, and Congressman Watt.
E.R.
Shipp, when you hear all of the things that are thrown into the pot, this is what's being argued, quite frankly, in Washington right now.
The Supreme Court nomination, you mean...
Yes.
...as well as some other things being argued in Washington.

With Judge Alito, I think, we have a much more solid record to look at than we had with Judge Roberts, now Chief Justice Roberts, and all the people who spend time on these kinds of issues have something with which to work.
So what we're listening to right now--I, by the way, am technologically disadvantaged because, like your previous guest, I did not get in on the whole conversation.

But in any case, what we're witnessing right now is the people who spend time on policy issues, the people I like to call the `wonks of life'--I include myself as one--are having time to really scrutinize this record.
And the more they scrutinize, the more they see that Judge Alito raises questions that really need to be seriously pursued.
Now whether the Congressional Black Caucus focuses only on anything related to affirmative action is another matter.

I would think that the CDC is more advanced than to just focus on one issue and that they, with their consultants, their lawyers, their advisers, etc., will be able to look at the totality of his record.
George Curry, you've been following this almost from day one, or from day one, I should suggest.
Talk to me about what you're hearing now.
We're seeing some fire from the Congressional Black Caucus, but we're also seeing fire from the right, personified by Mychal Massie there.
Look, let's put some context here.
Mychal Massie is basically a mouthpiece for the far, far right.
He--this is a person who in August said that John Roberts is the type of jurist who represented ...(unintelligible) of greater Americans such as James Madison and Martin Luther King.
There is nobody in their right mind who thinks that John Roberts carries out the ideas of Martin Luther King.
And that's why Mychal wouldn't qualify as being in that group.
Look, the CBC is not idiotic.
They have a broad agenda.

They know what's best, in our interests, and you have a small, tiny group, and Massie's a part of it, way out there who are well-funded, and they come out with whatever the right-wingers want, and they do not represent the thinking of the African-American community.
We can think for ourselves.

And so when people look at the record, with they look at the record right here with Alito, they can see that on most civil rights cases, he has been on the opposite side, and that's real cause for concern with him being on the court.
But, George, let me jump in again.
I'm sorry.
There is no one way of black thinking, so even in your comments you just indicated that black people know how to think for themselves.
We do, and we need to acknowledge that we're going to have all kinds of ways of thinking among...
There's no question about that.
I'm not--I don't disagree with that, but I'm saying--what I said was that mainstream African-Americans--i.e., 90 percent--generally, when it comes...
How do you measure that?
Hold on.
Hold on--Generally, when it comes to civil rights issues, there is an overwhelming majority point of view on questions like affirmative action and where people stand on the EEOC issue.
All right, Jeff, just jump in here because we've got an abbreviated session today.
I want to make sure that you get your equal...
